field.name: Title
field.definition: a phrase or groups of words, usually appearing on or in the resource, that names the work therein for purposes of identification and reference

dos.practice: This is a required, free text field.
When processing a record, take the title and do a search across all collections to see if there are any duplicates of the record in other collections.
Separate the title and the subtitle with a colon.
Capitalize the first word of a title and the first word of subtitles (e.g. An introduction to DART: A community facility for ensemble data assimilation).
Capitalize other words only as appropriate (e.g. Earth). Proper nouns, chemical abbreviations, instrument or model abbreviations and the titles of conferences should also be capitalized.

If the title indicates that the resource is a “part” of a larger whole, capitalize the P and use either Roman or Arabic numerals, as indicated within the title of the resource itself (e.g. The art of painting: Part 3)
When referring to entire books, the title and pubName fields should be completed with the same values.
When using Thesis/dissertation, append the degree name to the title. See examples below.

donts.practice: Do not end the title with any form of punctuation, unless it is part of the title itself.
Do not enter names of serial or periodic publications; that is do not enter the name of a journal.

examples.practice: The computational future for climate and Earth system models: On the path to petaflop and beyond
Thesis/dissertation - Masters: The saline flow into the Atlantic. M.S. thesis
Thesis/dissertation - PhD: The saline flow into the Atlantic. Ph.D. dissertation

otherPractice.header: Special Characters to Encode? Do This:
otherPractice.practice: All special characters like subscripts, superscripts, copyright and other symbols must be entity encoded numerically. See the numeric entity encodings.
